item.title: Portuguese | Study points to Brazil's lack of focus in Macau and China
item.description:
“Brazilian Foreign Policy and the Quest to Promote Portuguese: Building Bridges Through Macau”, a study by João Simões, from the City of Macau, and Daniel Veras, draws attention to the need for Brazil to bet more on the advantages of Macau in the promotion of Portuguese, as well as in China
A study recently published in Janus magazine, from the Autonomous University of Lisbon, draws attention to the fact that Brazil is not properly enjoying the advantages that Macau can offer in the promotion of the Portuguese language, integrated into the country's foreign policy. “Brazilian Foreign Policy and the Quest to Promote Portuguese: Building Bridges Through Macau” [Brazilian foreign policy and the issue of Portuguese promotion: building bridges through Macau] is authored by João Simões, assistant professor at the City of Macau (UCM ) and Daniel Veras, professor at the Pontifical Catholic University of Minas Gerais, in Brazil. “It is time for Brazil to have a more significant presence in Macao, not only through diplomatic channels, but also encouraging the involvement of several non -state actors, such as commerce and investment chambers, professional associations, Brazilian cultural centers, media organs , artistic and cultural foundations, among others ”, read in the article. Thus, the authors consider that this set of partners could help Brazil “leverage the role of Macau as a generator of opportunities, something that Brazil has not yet fully enjoyed”, since this “reinforced presence in Macau would allow the consolidation of Existing partnerships between Brazilian universities and mainland China ”. In addition, at the level of students, a more robust presence in Brazil in the MSAR could “bring Chinese students closer to Portuguese from Brazilian companies, reinforcing the connection between education and the business ecosystem of the great bay”, as well as to enhance the production of "Locally adapted didactic materials to the Chinese context and, ultimately, bringing Brazil and China closer to the unique environment that Macau offers." Based on official documents and other studies on this theme, the authors consider that, in general terms, there is “the need for Brazil effectively to take advantage of Macau's strategic position to capitalize on these opportunities”. Noteworthy among the main points of this position is the fact that, in Macao, the policy of “a country, two systems”, being “an International Porto, an autonomous customs zone” and having “a simple and reduced tax regime”, is noted among Macao. , without forgetting the role of commercial platform. Academics also refer to the “proper economic diversification plan for MSAR (2024-2028)” which “also offers opportunities, especially the promotion of key industries development such as traditional Chinese medicine, the modern financial industry, state -of -the -art technology and MICE (meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions) and culture and sports. A weak bet Regarding China, Brazil is also not exploring every opportunity, João Simões and Daniel Veras highlight. "Brazil's foreign policy has actively promoted the Portuguese language in certain geographies, but has not given priority to China, despite the importance of the bilateral relationship between the two countries." It is stated that “the Portuguese language is expanding in China, but Brazil's participation is not up to its magnitude as the largest Portuguese-speaking country in the world”. It is argued that this “discrepancy is even more surprising if we consider that China has been Brazil's largest commercial partner since 2009”. The study highlights Victoria Almeida's position on the origin of Portuguese teachers in China, which “historically the teaching of Portuguese in China was referenced teachers from Portugal”. Thus, “only recently teachers in Brazil became more predominant”, and one of the explanations pointed out to this is the creation of the reader program, which sends teachers to teach Portuguese worldwide. The situation of this program is mentioned in 2010, when "13 readers were selected, two of which placed in China: one in Bisu and one at Guangdong University of Foreign Studies." Still, "Brazil's didactic materials are scarce, and although there are Chinese students who want to go to Brazil, these opportunities are limited and the costs are high." It is understood that Brazil “could take advantage of what is happening with the teaching of Portuguese in mainland China”, because “after years of rapid growth in the number of Portuguese apprentices, we are now in an investment phase in the so-called area studies. or regional ”. Thus, “Brazilian higher education and research institutions can contribute to the reinforcement of China's area studies on Lusophone and Latin America countries, through the investigation and analysis of social, economic, political and cultural dynamics of the target regions ”, Especially given the initiative“ a track, a route ”, is stressed by the authors. Portugal does better The study denotes that, despite the various exchanges between Brazilian and Chinese higher education, the truth is that “many more Chinese students return from exchanges in Portugal, whose best universities offer exchanges with Chinese students”, considering that “it will take a long time until that Brazil builds a teaching culture in China ”. Thus, “compared to Brazil, Portugal has a greater framing in the teaching of Portuguese abroad”, providing “Teaching Programs and Scholarships for Chinese Students”, Master's and PhD level, without forgetting “Partnership with the Camões Institute ”. “Portugal also facilitates the acquisition of titles, as well as promoting the translation of Portuguese novels in China. On the other hand, Brazil does not make such a structured effort. As a result, currently, most Chinese Portuguese-speaking students tend to use European Portuguese as a base or at least as a reference, ”he says. Thus, João Simões and Daniel Veras consider that “Brazil can capitalize on the current context, which encompasses several favorable factors, to adopt a more collaborative approach to the promotion of Portuguese language in China”. The study states that, currently, Portuguese is spoken by more than 264 million people on five continents, and it is expected to rise to nearly 400 million people by 2050, with “the African continent responsible for the largest increase”, reinforcing The preponderance of Portuguese as one of the most spoken languages ​​in the southern hemisphere. In addition, Portuguese is an official or work language in 32 international organizations. With the arrival of Lula da Silva to the presidency of Brazil for the second time, the authors consider that he “has tried an approach to China”, namely in the commitment to join the initiative “a track, a route” and the appointment “of a representative permanent at the Macao Forum ”. The academics cite another author's idea regarding the existence of “distrust and reserve that Brazil has shown over the years in relation to the Macao Forum”. Greater involvement “can help to guarantee China access to vital resources and markets in Brazil and Africa, potentially contributing to China's food and internal energy security” as well as enhancing Macau as a “cultural channel between China and the World Lusophone ”. However, “although there is political will and a favorable environment in Macau, more concerted efforts will be needed by Brazil to materialize these opportunities,” is referred to.

item.title: Chinese New Year | Tourism and trips boosted consumption
item.description:
Arrived to the end of Chinese New Year's holidays, official numbers do not lie: China has crossed an intense consumption period, especially related to travel and tourism. Between January 28 and this Tuesday, some destinations in the country broke records of visitors
It is at the beginning of each year that the economy awaits the one who is one of the high moments for tourism and consumption in China. The Chinese New Year represents not only a moment of family life, but also the opportunity for many Chinese to travel. This year, to celebrate the year of the serpent, millions of people traveled internally and also out of the country between January 28 and Tuesday, and according to Xinhua the numbers are impressive with regard to purchases or number of visitors in some Destinations. The Altay City Hall, in the Xinjiang Autonomous Region, is referred to as one of the great ski destinations in the country, having received between January 28 and 31 191,900 visitors, a tourist flow that generated 225 million yuan in revenues. The agency points out that "skiing has definitely became the most popular activity in Altay during the holidays", leading to "a record number of practitioners, more than 10,000, to visit Jiangjunshan's ski resort on February 2". This represented "an increase of 23 percent over the previous year." The Altay zone is famous for registering between 170 and 180 days of snow per year, and in the mountainous areas the average snow depth reaches between one and two meters. Another region of China that reached considerable numbers on Chinese New Year holidays was Yangshuo County in the Autonomous Guangxi Zhuang region, thanks "to unique natural landscapes and rich cultural activities." Between January 28 and 30, this area received about 410,600 tourists, generating tourist revenues of 589 million Yuan. In turn, Lhasa (in Tibet) also registered an increase in the number of visitors. Between January 28 and Monday, the city received 1.95 million tourists, representing an increase of 20.6 percent over the previous year, and found in tourist revenues almost 1.76 billion Yuan. This is an increase of 14.75 percent compared to the previous year, according to the Lhasa Municipal Culture and Tourism Office. Positive data from agencies Also according to Xinhua, the Chinese New Year's numbers also revealed themselves on travel reserve platforms. In the case of Fliggy, one of the main online agencies, "an increase in reserves, especially for cities such as Shanghai, Beijing and Guangzhou" was recorded. On the other hand, "international travel orders have increased significantly, with international cruise reserves increasing more than six times compared to the previous year." Regarding air traffic, Shanghai Airport Group reported that passenger traffic on Sunday has reached a new historic record of 404,000 people, with Pudong Airport in Shanghai, to record 259,000 passengers and Hongqiao Airport 145,000 passengers. There was also a “reinforced coordination of the services of metro, buses and taxis to ensure transport without problems” with the arrival of the end of the holidays, said the group. On Monday, China State Railway Group Co., Ltd. recorded “a historic milestone” as they were transported on all railways a total of 16.45 million people. This is the “largest passenger traffic in a single day in the history of the Spring Festival Race”. Only this Tuesday, the last day of the holidays, will have traveled 16.9 million passengers, a number that highlights “further the peak of travel, since hundreds of millions of people returned to their destinations after family meetings” . Comes and Babies As far as tourism is concerned, it was found “a growing number of people who sought to know the heritage of China, motivated by the registration of the Spring Festival in the representative list of UNESCO's Immaterial Cultural Heritage, in December 2024”, indicates the state agency. Data from the Ministry of Commerce show that sales in major retail and restoration companies throughout China, during the first four days of holidays, increased 5.4 percent compared to the same period last year. There was an increase in consumption of imported food and drinks, such as lobsters, beer and wine. "Due to increased demand during the Spring Festival, our company's imports increased almost 50 percent last month," said Yang Xinyu, who represents a company in the Guangzhou -based international supply chain. Since January that the customs authorities of Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport have enlarged the importation of food products such as lobsters and crabs, 31.8 percent compared to 2024, translated the total of 14.3 million Yuan. Many online shopping And if the Chinese New Year is synonymous with family reunion, the holidays were once again a time for online shopping. Meituan, one of the country's leading electronic service platforms, has recorded an “impressive increase” of 300 percent over the previous year in online reserves for Lunar New Year's Eve dinners. Note that "group orders for packages with the theme" intangible cultural heritage "have increased more than 12 times since January, year after year, reflecting the growing interest of consumers in cultural experiences." Sun Jiashan, an associate researcher at the Central Academy of Culture and Tourism Administration, said, according to Xinhua, a change in consumer behavior, especially by young people and families. "Young families are increasingly becoming the driving force of consumption, with a tendency for diverse, high quality and culturally rich experiences," he said. Meituan Travel data corroborate the analyst's observation that young people increasingly choose to celebrate the Spring Festival in smaller cities, plunging into intangible cultural heritage and historical landmarks. The increase in tourism and cultural consumption, from equity experiences to successful films, indicate a growing demand for traditional and contemporary cultural activities. "This trend has also led to increased demand for cultural and tourist products and services, giving rise to the introduction of new models and business formats that adapt better to contemporary cultural consumption standards," Sun said, highlighting the potential of the Chinese consumer market and the internal driving forces of the economy. But not only shopping was made this Chinese New Year, because "the country's film industry proved to be one of the biggest winners during the spring festival's consumer wave." Between January 29 and February 3, the ticket daily revenues exceeded billion yuans for six consecutive days, raising the ticket offices of this year's Spring Festival to 8.02 billion yuans, According to China's movie administration data, China's total box office on this year's holidays, including real-time pre-sale, exceeded ten billion Yuan.

item.title: Denmark | PM Refusal Sell Grolândia
item.description: Denmark Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen was yesterday available to dialogue with the United States over Granelândia, stressing that the autonomous territory "is not for sale." "We have been very clear: we all have to respect the sovereignty of all states in the world - and Granelândia is today a part of the Denmark Kingdom - it is not on sale," he said. The Danish leader spoke at the entrance of the first EU leaders' retreat, an initiative created by European Council President António Costa for more informal debates. I totally agree with Americans that the region of the far north, the Arctic region, is increasingly important when we talk about defense and security and dissuasion, and it is possible to find a way to ensure a stronger [United States] footprint in Granelândia, where they are already, ”said Mette Frederiksen. The head of the Copenhagen government also recalled that Danish troops fought alongside the US for many decades. US President Donald Trump has claimed greater access to the Arctic and expressed the interest of acquiring Granelândia, an autonomous territory managed by Denmark.

item.title: Tourism | Analysis says that Macau is increasingly a leisure destination
item.description:
The academics Pedro Steenhagen and Sofia Xiaoying have analyzed the Macao Tourism Industry, concluding that, increasingly, the territory is viewed as a leisure destination and not as much as a gaming land. The authors warn of the “long way to go regarding the promotion of sustainable tourism”
The Macao Tourism sector has changed in recent years and the visions of the tourists themselves as well, facing the territory as a place where one can walk and enjoy leisure zones, not as much as a game land. This is one of the conclusions of the “Tourism as A Driver of China's Cultural Soft Power: The Role of Macau and the Convergences Between The New Silk Road and the Greater Bay Area” [Tourism as the engine of China's Soft Power: The Role From Macao and the convergences between the new silk route and the Great Bay area], by Pedro Steenhagen, Fudan University, and Sofia Xiaoying Hou, linked to the Xi'an University of International Studies. Analysis of the tourism industry at MSAR is one of the chapters of the book “The Palgrave Handbook on China-Europe-Africa Relations”, recently edited. Thus, it is concluded that “the perception of the image of Macau by tourists has been changing in the last 10 years, being the more and more seen as a place of leisure and vacation in general, and not specifically or purely as a game center. ” It is also added that “the image of masters as a tourist destination is in transition, and people visiting Macao have greatly valued their unique cultural attractions, including their architecture and gastronomy, the result of the mixture of Chinese and Portuguese cultures and inheritances” . However, the authors consider that "Macau still has a long way to go regarding the promotion of effective sustainable tourism." It is understood that sustainable tourism “must fully take into account its economic, social and environmental impacts, addressing the needs of visitors, sector, environment and related communities”. In this field, the authors highlight, quoting another author, that "Macau has made efforts to achieve good grades in these and other stories, as the tourism industry of MSA has been undergoing a" silent revolution "since the beginning of the pandemic." It is also noteworthy that, worldwide, the International Tourism Organization has created some guidelines on sustainability, creating “an important framework of sustainable tourism”. For this, “five fundamental pillars were proposed to evaluate the sustainability of the tourism sector of a state”, such as “tourism policy and governance; trade, investment, data and competitiveness; Employment, decent work and training; Reduction of poverty and social inclusion; and sustainability of natural and cultural environments ”. The Silk Route The academics also analyze the role of the Macao tourist sector in the strategy of “a track, a route”, noting that the territory “has been gaining a prominent role in local, regional and external policies, being an actor capable of improving the Tourism Silk Route and streamline tourism in the Great Bay region ”. Macau is understood to make new contributions to the way China presents its culture, because “due to existing heritage and tourist products, it presents the Chinese culture to foreign visitors through a new, more diverse lens that goes beyond traditional” . Thus, tourists are allowed, “especially in the Lusophone world, [create] a better connection and understanding of the country through common historical and cultural bonds”. With regard to the Great Bay project, it is also considered that both this region and the territory of Macao have “actively integrated the tourism development strategies in the BRI frame”, ie “Belt and Road Initiative”, English designation for “a track, a route”. Macao has “a diverse and distinct range of tourist resources, such as the arts, history, constructions and religious traditions, gastronomy, sport, museums, among others”, and local authorities have sought, according to the authors, “Mark its tourist industry, promoting 'Tourism+' with transfronic cooperation in the scope of bri”. The idea is to “create an image of Macau as a city with diverse cultures, integrating the sectors of tourism, entertainment, culture, sports, business, conventions and exhibitions, health care, recreation, technology and big events”. IMPROVEMENTS ON COURSE Pedro Steenhagen and Sofia Xiaoying Hou understand that the Macao government “has been trying to improve cultural soft power and increasing tourist attractiveness through product development, facilities improvement and advertising”, and “projects to improve Facilities such as hotels, restaurants, transport and digital tours. ” The example of two digital pathways created by the Cultural Institute, namely, in 2021, “The House of the Family of Zheng Guanying” and also “Fortaleza da Guia”. Moreover, authorities have created several interactive platforms using increased virtual reality. Despite all the efforts pointed out to the local authorities, it is understood that "masters still have an unexplored potential to reinforce cultural ties between China and Portuguese-speaking countries, and this decade may present great opportunities in this regard." The tourist bet In this chapter, the authors also look at the positioning of tourism in the initiative “a track, a route” by Beijing, given that “China has been increasingly paying attention to the need to expand its cultural soft power , both regional and global. ” Thus, the country "has formulated several cultural development plans associated with" a track, a route "and the area of ​​the great bay, and tourism has constantly appeared as an essential element of its global strategy.” In the country "tourism has gained relevance, either as a means of improving international image and as a source of revenue." Only in 2018 “about 159 million visitors traveled to the country, which invested $ 155 billion in tourist infrastructure-a value behind the United States, but should become the first by 2028- since you saw the sector represent 11 percent of your total gross domestic product. ” The authors argue that “by connecting and increasing the dynamics between BRI [Belt and Road Initiative] and the Great Bay area, with an interesting effort on the diversification of Macao's economy and strengthening its tourist sector, as well as among the objectives. National and regional, China seems to be finding a way to boost tourism and reap the fruits in terms of cultural soft power. ” Thus, and in the long run, it is considered that the country “may not only grow the power of its narratives and culture, but also improve normative power and institutional positioning in the world scene, especially with regard to issues of governance ”. It should be noted that the book “The Palgrave Handbook on China-Europe-Africa Relations” is edited by Yichao Li, Jorge Tavares da Silva, Carlos Rodrigues and Francisco José Leandro, from the University of Macau. The edition is in charge of Palgrave Macmillan.

item.title: USA | Trump will impose rates on “very soon” European products
item.description: United States President Donald Trump said European products will be subject to “very soon” customs rates following the imposition of tariffs on the importation of products from Canada, Mexico and China. “They are really enjoying us, we have a $ 300 billion deficit. They do not take our cars or our agricultural products, practically nothing, and we all bought millions of cars, huge levels of agricultural products, ”he said on Sunday to the press. The European Union lamented on the same day the increase in customs rates by the United States of America about products from Canada, Mexico and China, and said it will retaliate strongly if it is targeted by unfair tariffs. "The EU firmly believes that low customs rights promote economic growth and stability," the European Commission in a statement said through which he considered the imposition of more US tariffs as "harmful to all parties." If the European bloc is also the target of these measures, the community executive will “retaliate strongly”. Donald Trump signed on Saturday the executive order to apply customs rates to products from Canada, Mexico and China. The signature, which officializes the decision that had already been announced, determines the imposition of 10 percent rates to China, 25 percent to Mexico and 25 percent to Canada, except in Canadian oil, which will have a tariff of 10 per one hundred. Trump had threatened the imposition of tariffs to ensure greater cooperation from countries to prevent illegal immigration and the smuggling of chemicals such as Fentanil, an opioid that is causing important additions in the United States. The three countries promise to take action. Sacrifice (dis) necessary In the case of the European Union, a decision has not yet been made, but the concern is general and France defended on Sunday a "scathing response" of Europe in the face of threats of new customs tariffs by the US President. Trump admitted that the new tariffs can cause suffering to the American people, but has ensured that "everything will be worth it" because it will "make America big again." “Will there be suffering? Yes, maybe (and maybe not). But let's make America big again, and it will all be worth it, ”wrote Donald Trump, in capital letters, on the profile of the social network he founded, Truth Social, quoted by the France-Presse news agency.

item.title: Study | Greater life satisfaction associated with relationships and money
item.description:
A study that evaluates life satisfaction in 65 countries and regions, including China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, concludes that in all countries financial security and have a love relationship are key to happiness. However, during the pandemic there was a “great variability in global satisfaction”
What is necessary to have a full life with happiness? The question, which can have various connotations and spiritual trends, sought to be answered and quantified by the authors of the study “Life Satisfaction Around the World: Measurement Invariation of the Satisfaction With Life Scale (SWLS) Across 65 Nations, 40 Languages, Gender Identities, and Age groups ”[Life satisfaction around the world: Invariance on Life Sounding Scale (SWLS) in 65 countries, 40 languages, gender identities and age groups]. The study, recently edited by the academic magazine “Plos One”, started from analyzes made by dozens of academics and contributors in 65 countries and regions, including China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, which makes 57,000 people analyzed. In general terms, the authors conclude that "in all countries a greater satisfaction with life was significantly associated with financial security and the existence of a relationship of commitment or marriage." Thus, the results indicate that “greater satisfaction with life is significantly associated with greater financial security and higher educational qualifications (which may be an indicator of socioeconomic status, although the dimension of this specific relationship was insignificant)) ”. In general terms, “these results are consistent with the evidence that indicates that the satisfaction of basic human needs and material well-being is a strong-possibly the strongest-predictor of psychological well-being and life satisfaction and life specifically". Admittedly, the authors draw attention to the fact that the idea of ​​well-being can vary from country to country depending on the culture of populations, but the results “suggest that, when considered at the individual level, the association between satisfaction with Life and indicators of material welfare seems to be relatively robust between nations. ” Regarding relationships, the answers hung more to the importance of not being alone. “We found that marital status was significantly associated with life satisfaction. More specifically, we found that respondents in commitment relationships were more likely to report more life satisfaction than non -married. This result is consistent with the widest literature that shows that marital status is a robust correlate of psychological well-being. ” However, a satisfactory life is not directly linked exclusively to love relationships, and can also occur when the person has an active social life. "It has been suggested that the formation and maintenance of social relations is fundamental to the promotion of life satisfaction, particularly in cultures or communities that emphasize family values, because they satisfy a basic human need for belonging and are a source of positive affirmation." . In addition, it "reinforces healthy behaviors and protects against the impact of negative events." Thus, the study considers it to be "likely that people living in commitment relationships can report greater emotional support and social integration, which, in turn, contributes independently to life satisfaction." COVID-19 TIMES If socialization is regarded as very important to a satisfactory life, as it was in times of COVID-19, which forced long periods of confinement and isolation? The study resorted to specific and statistics to evaluate the issue, concluding that there was “great variability in global satisfaction with life in the context of Covid-19 pandemic. The respondents in Canada (Francophone) and Israel had the highest SWLs and respondents in Japan and Ukraine to have the lowest averages. ” Given the large dimension of the sample, the results allow you to conclude “that life satisfaction varied substantially among national groups at the height of the covid-19 pandemic, although the authors highlight,“ care is necessary to be careful when interpreting them Latent averages ”referred to at work so as not to advance with definitive conclusions. Still, academics understand that these data may be important to when "professionals and political decision makers try to understand differences in life satisfaction between nations," as well as being a "way to better support subjective well-being in the era Postpandmic ”. Also noteworthy is the least life satisfaction by the minority population groups. “We found that identification as part of a racialized minority was associated with less life satisfaction. Although this is consistent with some previous works and probably reflects the deleterious effect of the experiences of racism on life satisfaction, it should be noted that the dimension of the effect of this relationship was insignificant. ” In addition, the authors point out that “urbanity was associated with life satisfaction in a little significant way”, having been evaluated if living in a city or other urban context changed the level of satisfaction with life. Means and purposes To reach data from the SWLS scale described above, the “Body Image Inquiry” (Bins, English) was made by 253 scientists or academics of the 65 countries involved, who collected data between November 2020 and February 2022. In total, 56,968 people were interviewed, 58.9 percent were women, 40.5 percent men and 0.6 percent were of another gender identity. In terms of race and ethnicity, the majority, 74.2 percent, "identified as part of a racialized majority," while 11.3 percent "identified as part of a racialized or minority ethnic group." Regarding the site where participants live, 27 percent said living in a capital, 13.7 percent in the suburb of a capital, 25.1 percent in a province city, that is, with more than 100,000 inhabitants; While 18.7 percent said residing in a province town with more than 10,000 inhabitants. Only 15.5 percent of respondents lived in a rural area. As for literary qualifications, 33.5 percent ended higher education, 42 percent were single and 19.5 percent were in a “commitment relationship, but were not married”. In turn, 33.5 percent were married. Regarding financial security, 24.9 percent of participants reported feeling less safe than others of their age in their country of residence, while 49.6 percent said they felt “equally safe” and 25.5 percent They considered to be "safer". Inquiry data allowed the study authors to “examine associations between life satisfaction and the main sociodemographic variables at the level of the individual”. Factors such as “Life Satisfaction”, “Financial Security” and “Urbanity” were evaluated, in which participants filled SWLs using a 7 -point response scale, where 1 point represented “totally disagree” and 7 points "I totally agree." Demographic data such as age, education, marital status or race were also evaluated. With regard to China, the country is divided between “China - Cantonese”, “China - English” and “China - Mandarin”. In the case of “China - Cantonese”, regarding Hong Kong, 409 people responded, with 58 percent of women and only two percent of respondents belonging to a racial minority. All participants live in urban context, while 96 percent ended secondary or higher education. Of respondents, only two percent says it is in a relationship, whether or not marriage. In the case of “China - Mandarin” 1,231 people participated, 69 percent of which women, in which 95 percent resides in urban areas. 86 percent of respondents have a commitment or relationship.

item.title: Study | Academics highlight Christmas “egocentric” side as opposed to the lunar year
item.description:
A study of three Chinese academics states that while the Chinese New Year has a smaller smaller caress and "is clearly representative of contemporary Chinese society," "Christmas in the West is egocentric, exalts individuality and shows more interactivity." However, the work, published in a magazine of the State University of Bahia, points to the greater convergence of cultural characteristics
Chinese New Year and New Year: How are, what do they represent for the West and the East, and what are the points of convergence? It is to these questions that the study “Comparisons of cultures between Chinese New Year and Western Christmas” by Zhen Zhao, Yin Xuelu and Qiao Jianzhen intends to answer. Academic work was recently published in the magazine “Points of Interrogation - Journal of Cultural Criticism”, from the State University of Bahia, Brazil. The authors highlight, in general terms, that "Christmas in the West is egocentric, exalts individuality and shows greater interactivity", namely with the "participation of the crowd" and demonstration of "passionate carnival emotions of people". On the other hand, the Chinese New Year “is a national festival, clearly representative of contemporary Chinese society”. In general terms, this kind of celebrations emerges described as “a special sociocultural meaning that intersperses the daily routines”, “a concentrated exhibition of people's colorful life” as well as “a summary and extension of politics, economics, culture and religion from various regions, ethnic groups and countries. ” They also describe the authors that the Chinese New Year, who can also be called the Lunar New Year or Spring Festival, has roots “in a small peasant economy and is often based on Confucianism, with a mixture of Buddhist and Taoist culture”, being linked to "feudal religious rituals." In turn, Christmas is presented as a larger religious component, being "rooted in Western Christian culture and embodies the values ​​of freedom and equality, original sin and individualism everywhere." Inevitable interconnections However, the study describes as inevitable the future exchange of cultural demonstrations at these times of the year: in the case of Christmas, in December; In the case of the Chinese New Year, during the months of January and February of each year, depending on the calendar. "The future exchange of Chinese and Western cultures, including the festival's culture, is an inevitable part of social and historical development," is described, as well as "an evolutionary process of complementarity between Chinese and Western cultures." Thus, the authors say, the contact points should be discovered by both cultures “from the differences between the Chinese New Year and Christmas, so that they can be promoted” and so that there is a greater preservation of “their national cultures. ”. The authors say they “the acceleration of cultural exchange between the East and the West” in this field, as “Chinese celebrate Western festivals and foreigners celebrate Chinese festivals”. "In the age of globalization, and due to the development and deepening of economy and culture, traditional Chinese and Western parties have been gradually accepted by both peoples in mutual tolerance," reads. Differentiating points The three authors of the study recall that in China, the most traditional festivals have a connection with agriculture, with traditional customs based on food and drink. "The main reason for this is the pursuit of the Chinese people in going to be oriented to a long and healthy life." Meanwhile, "Western traditional festivals have mainly origin in religion and related events," therefore "strong religious connotations." It is added that, in the West, “traditional vacation customs are based mainly on the subject of fun”, the main reason for “the pursuit of western ones in life to have the objective of health and happiness”. In comparative terms, "both Chinese New Year and Christmas is a family reunion time and a wonderful time for people to look back and also to the future," although "with different connotations in Chinese and Western cultures." One of the differences pointed out in the study is the way the days before these dates are celebrated. “The year's passage [in the Chinese New Year] is the time when people try to go home to their loved ones, no matter where they are. New Year's dinner is the highlight, also known as the reunion dinner, being the most important meal of the year. ” One of the rituals goes through the sunset, “families start to light the rockets”, starting to prepare meals with this environment. “Although New Year's dinner dishes range from place to place, each dish has a certain symbolic meaning. Chinese like to use harmonics to attract good luck, and for example, chicken harmonics mean 'auspicious', while "yu" yu harmonics mean "year after year". “New Year's Eve is a custom of the Chinese people Han. After eating the New Year's meal, people gather in family to wait for the coming of the new year at midnight, ”the authors point out, also describing that“ in many parts of China on New Year's night, People prepare sumptuous offerings, light incense and candles, pour wine and burn paper money, paying tribute to family ancestors to express nostalgia for them ”, as well as waiting for blessings“ for the sons and grandchildren of the sky, inspiring the descendants to work harder and live up to the desires of their ancestors. ” In the case of Christmas, celebrated on December 25, the day before is marked by a family dinner that also has traditional dishes and sweets, such as the king cake, cod or roast turkey. “Unlike New Year's Chinese vigil, Westerners celebrate Christmas as a unique fantasy party on Christmas Eve who extends throughout the night. At the party there is no rigorous clothing code, just being natural and informal, climbing to say 'Hello' and sending sincere wishes [of good holidays], ”is mentioned. Another differentiating point pointed out is the offers. If the Chinese New Year is usual the offer of money in the “Lai Si” envelopes, the western Christmas are present between family and friends. The distribution of money in the Chinese New Year has several connotations, and there is a kind of money to the elders, serving “to wish them a long life”; While there is later the money given from the elders to the youngest, representing a care transmission from the most seniors. In turn, “the first legends about Christmas gifts refer to the birth of Jesus,” with the offerings of the wise men. “It is currently customary to give gifts between family and friends at Christmas,” is mentioned, and there is also the idea that it is Santa to distribute the gifts. “Sometimes people pretend to be Santa Claus to give gifts to children in order to add the festive spirit,” he says. Another big difference pointed out by the study is that in the West, Christmas does not have the same connotation as ancestors. “In the West people do not worship their ancestors, and people go to church to celebrate the birth of Jesus. People are not limited to being in family meetings, but inviting [others] in a warm way to their homes, and is not considered rude partying together. During the holidays many people participate in community activities to help the poor and give gifts, reflecting the idea of ​​seeking equality. ” Similarity According to the study, the two celebrations have as its common point to serve to "maintain social stability." “In ancient China agricultural production was strongly influenced by the climate. Poor workers who belonged to the lower classes often had to work all year round, which inevitably led to dissatisfaction with the reality of the situation. ” In this sense, the arrival of the Chinese New Year is “a good time to release emotions”, decorating the house and lighting rockets in the creation “hope that the next year will be good, with good harvests and better days”. With regard to Christmas, it is described that people “go to church worship [the saints], sing Christmas songs and pray to God, hoping that they will help them get out of difficulties when they are in trouble or when they are sick and face death . They expect God to forgive them for the sins so that they can ascend to heaven after death, ”there is a parallel with the“ liberation of emotions ”above. In addition, both celebrations constitute forms of culture transmission, according to the authors of the study. “New Year's culture is an accumulation of traditional Chinese culture, being the crystallization of the work and wisdom of the Chinese people, expressing the aspirations of the hardworking people who long for good things.” In addition, these celebrations “carry and convey traditional culture in a subtle manner”, namely with paintings and other decorations of houses, or events such as Dragon and Lion dances or handwriting sessions. “Through these activities the extremely valuable cultural heritage is transmitted to younger generations,” is referred to. In turn, at Christmas there are the decorations of the time, with the tree, the lights or cribs, in green, red colors and other bright tones. “People who have been busy working year returns to revive the family heat. People go to the church to celebrate the birth of Jesus, which is a regular event and an inheritance of religious culture. It has become customary to send a Christmas card to friends and family, and all these customs carry profound cultural connotations that are transmitted. ”

item.title: Portugal Day | Marcelo in the celebrations in Macau
item.description:
Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa's passage has no date yet, but will fall into the celebration of Portugal's Day, Camões and Portuguese communities, in a year when official celebrations will take place in Lagos, Algarve, and then in Macao

It is a gesture of recognition by the President of the Republic of the relevance and dimension of the Portuguese community, which as we know is not restricted to the Portuguese immigrants, expatriates, Portuguese from Portugal, but all those who have Portuguese nationality and live in Macau and that are many. There are many tens of thousands, ”said Alexandre Leitão, in statements to the station. "I am sure that the Portuguese community is brothers in the same joy and satisfaction and that together we will know how to receive the President of the Republic with the gratitude that this gesture deserves to us," he added. Also to the Macau channel, Miguel de Senna Fernandes, president of the Macaense Instruction Promoter Association was pleased with the news. “Obviously it is not just a mere view, it is a visit by the President of the Republic, linked to a special day that is June 10. It is not every day that Macau receives a visit from the President of the Republic, although it is not the first time, ”he began by highlighting Senna Fernandes. “It is always good to know what the Portuguese state thinks about Macau, the presence of Portuguese culture […] beyond the discourses we are used to listening, it is important to know how the Portuguese state sees the presence of the Portuguese community in Macau. item.title: Works | Ella Lei calls for coordination to reduce impact on the population
item.description:
The deputy of the workers anticipates the increase of major works in the main roads of cities throughout this year, and asks the government to take steps to reduce the impact on traffic, local commerce and the lives of residents
Deputy Ella Lei argues that the government should promote a better coordination of road works, to avoid traffic embarrassment that affect residents, as well as business in the areas of the work. The subject was addressed by the legislator linked to the Federation of Macao Workers Associations (Faom) through written interpellation. According to the figures presented by the deputy, the coordination group of works on the roads of Macau has received 69 proposals for construction projects related to the government or the water companies, telecommunications or electricity, which represents an annual increase of 15 by one hundred. Among these projects, 39 will take place for more than 30 days in the main arteries of the city, a proportion that Ella Law indicated a 39 percent increase in the number of projects with great impact on traffic. "Many groups of citizens are concerned about the current situation of road projects and expect the government to continue to improve the coordination and monitoring mechanism of projects," says the deputy. “For example, information about traffic deviations should be disclosed as soon as possible, even before the start of road projects, and residents' opinions should be continually heard in order to minimize the impact on business and travel of people, ”he added. More information In this context of growing constraints, the deputy asks: “Will authorities take more measures in the process of coordinating large road projects, such as optimizing global planning and supervision work, to solve long -term problems caused by road projects to residents? ”He asked. Among the suggestions made, the deputy wants to know if the government will create an online platform to receive citizens' opinions, about improvements that can be implemented as long as the projects are taking place. On the other hand, Ella Lei argues that another easily accessible platform should be created with information about regularly updated works. Ella Lei also appealed to the government to control the quality of the materials used in the works, and indicated that the use of unfair materials, which eventually damage the roads, is often used.

item.title: Macao in 2025
item.description: After taking office as a sixth chief executive of Macao, Sam Hou Fai announced that in the next five years he would strive to realize the four great visions: "Macau founded in the rule of law, dynamic, cultural and happy." Will these four views be really realized in 2025, the first year of the new Government of MSAR? To achieve these four objectives, RAE's sixth government has to actively engage with patriotic organizations for communication and exchange purposes, and take government officials to Beijing to listen to Xia Baolong's instructions, the Director of the Work Office Hong Kong and Macao from the Communist Party Central Committee of China and the Hong Kong and Macao affairs office with the Council of State. All of this will be necessary to prepare the first report of the Governing Lines of Action to be presented by the Sixth Government of MSAR. Based on reports from all over, and changes from members of the Management Committee and the Executive Committee of the Deepened Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macao in Hengqin, it seems that the “integration of Macao and Hengqin” will probably be a priority topic of the future policies of RAE. This is because this is a national policy defined by the central government for the sectoral diversification of the Macao industry and for the efficient integration of Macau in the Great Guangdong-Hong Bay Kong-Macau. Although the path has already been opened, to prevent Macao from becoming confused with any other city in the interior of China, the proposal of the four visions is undoubtedly necessary. The question that remains is how to reach them. Firstly, about the view of “Macao founded in the rule of law”, some scholars believe that “the law should not just be a tool for the government to control society. If we want to speak of a rule of law, the people must also be able to exercise control over government action through the law; This bilateral supervision is what constitutes the rule of law. Otherwise, the “rule of law” would mean controlling the people through legal provisions. Therefore, the concept of Sam Hou Fai of “Macao based on the rule of law” must be persecuted in the direction of the rule of law, and not through the formulation or alteration of legal documents to control the people and society. As for the creation of the “dynamic Macao”, the key is to break the limitations of the region. Otherwise, the coming of more tourists will only make the whole city chaotic, moving away from the goal of becoming the world center of tourism and leisure. To increase the vitality of Macao, it is necessary to expand its territory. Hengqin is no longer a new zone directly under jurisdiction in the city of Zhuhai to become a deepened cooperation zone built and run jointly by Guangdong and Macau province. The next step is undoubtedly moving towards the integration of Macau and Hengqin. Anyone with a basic understanding of public administration knows that having two power centers and two leadership teams often affects administrative efficiency and reduces its effectiveness due to the lack of unified authority. Therefore, when the central government fully transfer the administration of Hengqin to Macau, it should also be the time to materialize the "dynamic Macau". Macau has only a few hundred years of history compared to the thousands of years of China's cultural heritage. But what makes Macau stand out among many Chinese cities? The sino-Portuguese cultural and religious fusion. The files of the Diocese of Macao, Synical Sheets, and “Files and Manuscripts of the Kong Tac Lam Macau Temple (1645-1980)” were included in the registration of the memory of the UNESCO world to ASIA and PACIFIC, which fully demonstrates to Singularity of Macao's culture. If this advantage can be used, transforming Macau into “Macao Cultural” should not be difficult As for the “Macao Happy” view, it should be the main priority of the Government of MSAR. After pandemic, affected by several internal and external factors, Macau's small and medium -sized companies faced difficulties, and social progress lacks driving force, with the increase of suicide incidents. The Government of MSAR has the responsibility of preventing Macau, “governed by patriots”, becomes a tragic city. For Macao residents to feel happy, it is essential to concentrate not only in the material aspects, but also in their mental well-being. With the strong support of the central government and Sam Hou Fai's efforts and his team, 2025 is expected to be the best year of the next decade.

item.title: Refreshing vulvar and shame
item.description: Recently, a celebrity in Portugal has launched a product that has given to talk, generated numerous posts and even made some paint. It is an intimate bruma, suggestively called Pipy, available by 29.90 euros. The goal? Refresh and somehow empower women to feel good with their bodies. I always suspect the media of certain products. This was undoubtedly created "to ask them." The usual criticism followed: feminists with the arguments of the custom-many of which I subscribe to soul and heart-supported by health professionals. These are recurring discourses, because reality persists: there is a whole industry that thrives at the expense of female insecurity. Society insists on generating a feeling of dedequation in relation to normal body processes. If you want to refresh your vulva, wash it with water-the effect will probably be the same. In addition, products like this, created from an artificial need, can bring more problems than solutions. The vagina has a sophisticated cleaning system and doesn't need new formulas to “clean yourself better”. Interfering with this balance can cause pH imbalances, making the intimate zone more susceptible to infections such as candidiasis and bacterial vaginosis. And then, yes, smell and discomfort become a clinical problem. What bothers me is the discursive dance around these themes. On the one hand, there are those who see the existence of a product as an act of empowerment; On the other, there are those who, tirelessly, try to educate for a healthier relationship with the body. Now one thinks that there is a product is to empower the vulves, while others try to educate for happy vulvas. And we stayed like this. The latter preach for the deaf, and the first preach stupidity. What is the discursive opportunity of these vaginal refreshing, what pedagogical opportunities are we waste? A sincere conversation about people's badness. Why do people feel the need to buy products to hide the natural smell of their private parts? Although manufactured, insecurity and discomfort are still real, touching a sensitive point of existence: the shame. Shame is a complex emotional system, based on beliefs that have been blaming the vulves because they are as they are. Also based on millennial discursive traditions. In ancient Greece they explained that men had a less poignant smell than women, so they needed more delicate perfumes, and women perfumes that best covered their natural aroma. Dealing with shame is not easy - it requires delicacy. Explain that this is a manufactured shame does not make it disappear by magic. Continuous experiences of understanding are needed so that shame dissolves and becomes a true state of empowerment. Pipy is pseudo-popping because it works like a fast, temporary relief for deeper insecurity. The discussions that we have watched also perpetuate ideological chapels, easy to predict, without great emotional and empathic depth. This will be only one of many articles written about Pipy, but perhaps the only one with the modest purpose of claiming that shame is being seen and understood. We were taught to be ashamed of the vulva. To unlearn, to achieve real empowerment, we have to look at this shame with affection and understanding. This recognition would be a first step to collective liberation. Only then will we leave the vulves finally at peace.

Today starts the sixth edition of the Photography Contest promoted by Somos - Portuguese Language Communication Association, and this time has as its main theme the religions and beliefs that exist in the world of Portuguese speakers. “Man and the Divine” is the theme that candidates photographers should follow in the name of a “greater understanding of different ideologies” Image of António Mil-Homens
The sixth edition of the Macau Somos Association Photographic Contest! - Portuguese Language Communication Association (ACLP) wants to contribute to a “greater understanding of the different ideologies and creeds” between the regions where Portuguese is spoken, the organization told Lusa. “The question of understanding is closely related to ignorance that persists between the various ideologies and creeds in the countries and regions of Lusophony. Through photography, we intend to explore this cultural and religious diversity, ”said Somos's president! - ACLP, Marta Pereira. Under the theme “Man and the Divine”, the contest, which starts today and takes place until March 10, wants to “promote coexisting dialogue between religions or traditional local beliefs,” he noticed. "The images must capture the essence of devotion, contemplation and the profound connection between humanity and the divine or the transcendent," said the official, adding that "it is fundamental" that the works "allow a historical contextualization, reflecting the various influences cultural and religious that shape spiritual experiences in different regions ”. Marta Pereira recalled that, in Macao, "the most practiced 'religion' is Buddhism, often associated with elements of other traditional Chinese beliefs and philosophies, such as Confucianism and Taoism." There is also a strong presence of "Christianity, brought to Macao by Catholic and Protestant missionaries." “If we look at Brazil, candomblé, a religion of African origin, is based on the worship of nature and its soul, and is therefore considered soul. In Timor-Leste, the population still remains rooted in the cult of ancestors and belief in spirits, ”he exemplified. To whom it is intended The competition, defines the regulation, is intended “to all citizens of the countries and regions of Lusophony or residents of Macau” with work done in Angola, Brazil, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Macao, Mozambique, Portugal, Sao Tome and Prince, Timor-Leste and Goa, Damão and Diu. The assessment of the candidate works is up to a jury chaired by the Portuguese photojournalist in Macau Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro and also with António Leong (Macau), Samba M. Baldé (Guinea-Bissau) and José Sena Goulão, Reinaldo Rodrigues and Alexandre Coelho Lima (Portugal). The three winning images will be awarded prizes worth ten thousand patacas, seven thousand patacas and five thousand patacas, and honorable mentions can be conferred. In addition to the pecuniary prize, the first place will be contemplated with the trip and stay in Macao -if not reside in the territory -to participate in the opening ceremony of the usual exhibition of Somos -ACLP, to be organized later this year, and in ' Locally organized workshops. In addition to the winning images, the exhibition completes other photographs selected by the jury “for its relevance or value” for the theme of the contest and “the purpose of the association of projecting the cultural dimension of Lusophony, as well as the role of Macao as a platform that unites China and the countries/regions of Portuguese Language ”, read in a statement from the Association.

item.title: “I'm still here” highlighted in the Goya awards
item.description: Walter Salles's “I'm still here” won the category of best Ibero-American movie in the Goya awards in a ceremony that attributed “Emilia Perez”, a work of Jacques Audiard involved in controversy, the title of best European film. This is the first time that a Brazilian feature film has been recognized in Goya, and director Walter Salles, through a message read by Uruguayan musician Jorge Drexler, expressed gratitude for this “very special” award. He remembered, moreover, that the work is about the memory of a family “during the long night of the military dictatorship in Brazil”. The film recalls the story of former deputy Rubens Paiva, who was arrested, tortured and killed by the Brazilian dictatorship in 1971, and his wife, activist and lawyer Eunice Paiva, who had to resume family life with her children, and who tried to complain justice for the death of her husband, whose body was never found. The lead roles are played by Fernanda Torres and Selton Mello. Audiard Also this Saturday, "Emilia Perez", by French director Jacques Audiard, won the award for best European film. The music film tells the story of a leader of a drug cartel who fulfilled the desire to make the transition to women. The victory of “Emilia Perez” was announced during the ceremony in Granada, but the vote ended on January 24, a few days before the beginning of the contagonist's polemics generated by the protagonist, Karla Sofa Gastón, published for years, some with Racist content. In these publications, released in late January by an American journalist, Gascon described Islam as a “focus of infection for humanity” and mocked the anti-racist movement after the death of George Floyd, African-American killed by police in 2020 . The Spanish press had been speculating for some time about the possibility of Gascon, who had to cancel his presence at various events in the United States, attend the Goya ceremony. But the actress, who lives near Madrid, eventually did not move to Granada. “Emilia Pérez” hit the record for the non -English language movie more appointed to the Oscars, with 13 nominations, among which for better film, international film, realization, photography direction, main actress and secondary actress. The feature film, which has been a success since the presentation in the Cannes Film Festival, has been the target of another controversy in recent weeks, this time in Mexico, where it was criticized for lightly appropriating tragedies linked to drug trafficking . Still in Granada, Spaniard Marcel Barrena's “El 47” was the film that raised the largest number of awards, in a total of five goyas (film, secondary actor, secondary actress, production direction and special effects). He shared the best film award with “La Infiltrada”, by Aragentxa Echevarría, which was also worth Carolina Yuste the title of best actress. Eduard Fernández, protagonist of ‘Marco’, held by actor Arregi and Jon Garaño, took home the best actor award. “La Stralla Azul”, Spanish and Argentina co -production, directed by Javier Macipe, won the best newcomer and revelation actor categories. item.title: Electric | Joe Chan says it is impossible to achieve inland goals
item.description:
Although last year 31.4 percent of the new vehicles recorded in the territory are electric, the president of Macau Green Student Union does not believe that the renewal of the Auto Park in Macau can achieve the objectives proposed by the interior
Environmentalist Joe Chan Chon Meng told Lusa that it is “absolutely impossible” Macau to reach the goal for electric vehicles in mainland China, from 45 percent of new sales by 2027. In early January, the Chinese government released a list of objectives Environmental, which includes a rise review of the previous goal for electric vehicles, which was 20 percent by 2025. In the second half of last year, the tramful ones represented more than half of the sales of new vehicles, according to data from the China passenger automobiles association. In Macao, 31.4 percent of the new vehicles recorded in 2024 were electric, according to official data. But the president of Macau Green Student Union stressed that fossil -powered vehicles “continue to represent a great proportion” of the territory park. At the end of December, Macau had a total of 253,182 vehicles, of which 12,302 vehicles (4.8 percent) were existing electric, according to the direction of services for traffic issues (DSAT). Still, Joe Chan stressed that in recent years, the government has implemented several measures to promote less polluting transportation, including the creation of more loading spaces for electric vehicles. Farther At the end of 2023, Macao had 2,100 electric charging places for light cars and 500 for motorcycles, indicated the direction of Environmental Protection Services (DSPA) on his portal. Authorities launched in 2023 a financial support plan for the slaughter of obsolete motorcycles and new electrical motorcycle replacement of a maximum of eight thousand patacas. According to DSAT, in 2024 Macao had 128,542 motorcycles, and only 3.5 percent were electrical, an increase of 1.4 percentage points over the previous year. Joe Chan suggested that authorities start by restricting heavy goods from goods, namely those used in construction, and public transport, "since Zhuhai [the city neighboring Macau] and border zones use natural gas and electricity." On Wednesday, DSAT officials told Radio Macau's Chinese channel that there are 929 new energy buses in operation, representing more than 92 percent of the total, while the proportion of more polluting buses descended to about 3 percent. As for taxis, there are only only electrical in circulation, representing about 11.9 percent of the total number, while the hybrid taxis represent about 86.2 percent of the total. "However, when it comes to highly polluting vehicles, such as trucks and heavy motorcycles, authorities have not yet defined a very clear calendar and deadline for their progressive elimination, so pollution [they cause] is high." , lamented the environmentalist.

item.title: Lusophony | Exports to China fell 5.3% in 2024
item.description: Exports from Portuguese -speaking countries to China fell 5.3 percent by 2024 to $ 139.7 billion, according to official data. According to information from China's customs services, the descent was mainly due to the largest Lusophone supplier in the Chinese market, Brazil, whose sales fell 5.2 percent to $ 116.1 billion. In addition, also the second largest Chinese commercial partner in the Lusophone block, Angola, saw exports decrease 6.7 percent to $ 17.6 billion by 2024. On the contrary, Portugal's sales sales to China increased $ 8.9 percent to $ 3.17 billion, while Mozambique exports rose 1 percent to $ 1.81 billion. Equatorial Guinea exports to the Chinese market dropped 28 percent to $ 981.7 million, while Timor-Leste sales (minus 98.8 percent), Cape Verde (less 80.9 percent) and Sao Tome and Principe (less 74.8 percent) also fell compared to 2023. Guinea-Bissau exports to China fell 43.4 percent by 2024, although the country did not sell more than 1,000 dollars in goods. In the opposite direction, Chinese exports to Portuguese -speaking countries increased 16.5 percent last year and reached a new record, $ 85.5 billion. The data reveal that Brazil was the largest buyer in the Lusophone block, with imports from China to reach $ 72.1 billion, a 21.9 percent rise in annual terms. Second on the list comes Portugal, which bought the goods in the amount of $ 6.11 billion, 5.5 percent than in 2023.
